title: FFELP Student Loan Defaults Are on the Rise and the CFPB Asks Why
text:
FFELP Student Loan Defaults Are on the Rise and the CFPB Asks Why Written by: John Sandman 10/22/15 - 9:51 AM EDT 
The Department of Education’s call for broke borrowers to take advantage of income-driven repayment plans continues to fall on deaf ears, according to a report released last week by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), which concludes that almost a third of the student loans taken out under the Federal Family Education Loan Program (FFELP) have either defaulted or become delinquent. 
The FFELP program, where the federal government backstopped student loans made by private lenders, was shut down by the Obama administration in 2010 and replaced by the Federal Direct Loan program, which eliminated financial institutions that acted as middlemen. 
The CFPB estimates that 95% of borrowers of these federally-backed, privately-originated loans who were eligible for income-driven repayment plans had not enrolled, even as ED promotes them as the solution of choice for people who are struggling to pay off their loans. More Headlines 5 Everyday Services You're Paying Too Much For 
“Today’s report found that Federal student loans made by private lenders may have a greater rate of borrowers in default and delinquency than the broader student loan market,” Seth Frotman, the CFPB’s acting student loan ombudsman wrote in an October 14 blog post. “This raises concerns about whether distressed borrowers with these loans are getting adequate information on repayment options from their servicers.” 
The CFPB also found that there has been a 23% spike in borrower complaints for private and federal loans. 
Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert took exception with the CFPB's view on the access borrowers had to income-based repayment. "The CFPB statement about FFELP borrowers having a right to income-based repayment isn't entirely accurate,” he said. “FFELP lenders are not required to offer IBR and cannot offer ICR or PAYER," the income-contingent repayment program and the Pay As You Earn program , respectively. 
"If a FFELP lender doesn't offer IBR, the borrower has the right to consolidate into Direct Lending to get IBR," Kantrowitz said. "But the FFELP lender is not required to tell this to the borrower under current law.” 1
